you know put your data for the most part on s3 right and yes data can be in other sources but fundamentally if the data is
consolidated on s3 then I can enable what I would call the three key features
of the data Lake and the first being separating compute and storage right and so are bringing the right amount of
compute to the processing power that's needed then not using the compute when it's not needed right and not not using
HDFS right so you know not paying the triple replication tax that HDFS but
having you know these open file formats like park' and Orci and JSON and Avro but having them just on s3 itself right
and then by having them on s3 like I would then enables the idea of collaboration so having this flexible
set of analytic tools from AWS and other partners that can then you know access that data on s3 and so how does a tool
like redshift and which is our data warehousing service and redshift spectrum how does it know about a file
on s3 well it has to have either a hive Metis store configured or from AWS we
have a service called the glue data catalog right which provides this high of meta story API which simply says I've
got files in s3 but I've got you know sequel queries that I need to access and so the the glue data catalog provides
that metadata repository so it doesn't move the data but simply provides a table store that map ultimately defiles on s3 right
and then because we're using s3 which is simply a object store right so s3 is not a database but the file format matters
and so a lot of times you might want to convert CSV files JSON files to things like parquet or RC or Avro and so we
also have this server list query or data transformation service called the glue execution engine that provides a server
less spark container such that your application developers or people that are doing data transformation can worry
about their code whether it's Python code to be able to express the transformations but then we provide a
server list spark container to execute that called the glue the AWS glue right
to actually do the execution of the transformations so once I have my file formats you know in the right shape and
they're presented in the glue data catalog I can now say well am i doing what I might think about data discovery
where attributes like schema on read and and sort of like having analysts that
want to know sequel but have uncertain patterns that just need a simple way to access that data they have we have a
service called Amazon Athena so Athena provides a completely serverless access through sequel to data on s3
there's no cluster to configure there's there simply a very simple payback query model where analysts you know can either
use ODBC JDBC or the API to just issue sequel directly against these open file
formats on s3 right and then I contrast that so what I might call a data warehousing workload where you know in
data warehousing the schemas are well known right the access patterns are fairly well known and that's really
where you know a cost-based optimizer and having you know local disk for complex sequel joins makes a lot of
sense and that's really the sweet spot for redshift right so redshift is our strategic product from AWS for data
warehousing and now with redshift spectrum we can extend our data warehouse to all of our data on s3 as
well right and so with spectrum I'm not using the local redshift cluster to query the data I'm using a server list
compute layer called spectrum to query that data but from a table perspective from the BI user perspective they're

on s3 and then for the end user that really prefers programmatic access to data you know using Apache Hadoop
